awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Diversity, Dominance & Disturbance in Species-Rich Pine Savanna Groundcover
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will test two likely mechanisms for the maintenance of biological diversity in natural habitats, the creation of fine-scale variation in the environment by dominant plant species and by natural disturbance by fire.  Some of the most diverse plant communities in North America are found in the fire-prone longleaf pine forest of the southeastern United States.  Although the forest canopy generally has only a few species of plants, and the plants beneath are often dominated by one or two species of large, long-lived bunchgrasses, a high number of smaller plant species can be found scattered between the grasses.  Researchers will experimentally alter interactions between bunchgrasses, interactions between bunchgrasses and smaller plants, and environmental conditions such as fire intensity to show how dominant plant species influence the diversity and dynamics of high-diversity plant communities in environments prone to disturbance.
 
Longleaf pine ecosystems historically covered most of the Atlantic and Gulf Coastal Plains, but human activities such as fire suppression have reduced the area of the forests by more than 98%.  This project will inform efforts to manage and restore these ecosystems.  In particular, a workshop will bring together land managers, conservation professionals, and ecologists to synthesize relevant information about these ecosystems, identify important gaps in our understanding of these floristic treasures, and translate the results into recommendations for conservation, management, and restoration.  In addition, the project will train undergraduate and graduate students in science and provide educational outreach activities for K-12 students and educators.

por.por_cntn:
Fewer studies are set in high-diversity plant communities than in low-diversity communities because experiments in the former are necessarily complicated. As such, there remains much to learn about how so many plant species can occur alongside each other. In these systems there are typically a few common species and many more relatively rare ones. Interactions among the common or dominant species may reflect important processes underlying the assembly of plant communities because common species are more likely to interact both with one another and with rare species than are rare species to interact with each other.

Longleaf pine savannas in the southeastern United States are among the most species-rich habitats on Earth. Thirty or more species of flowering plants are often packed into a small area of groundcover only one meter square. This was the dominant ecosystem along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts when early Europeans arrived. Because of habitat destruction and fire suppression, very little is left of the formerly vast pine savannas. We aimed to better understand the ecological processes that govern these special habitats, both for the sake of basic knowledge about the formation of plant communities, and to restore the longleaf ecosystem and better manage what remains.

For our main experiment, we removed wiregrass, the physically dominant bunchgrass species, from groundcover plots at Eglin Air Force Base in the Florida panhandle. We paired these bunchgrass-removal plots with control plots where we left wiregrass and everything else intact. We anticipated one of three possible outcomes: (1) bunchgrass removal could reduce the number of species there, (2) increase the number of species there, or (3) cause no change in number of species, depending on how wiregrass interacts with other species in the groundcover community. We conducted our experiment on a gradient from drier upland sandhills to wetter seepage slopes. Compared to wiregrass-removal, habitat had a very strong influence on species composition and biodiversity. To our surprise, we found essentially no change in species number after we removed wiregrass, suggesting that wiregrass had little direct effect on its immediate neighbors despite its dominance. It may be that our 4-year manipulation was too short and that a longer-term study would yet see changes. Regardless, wiregrass is thought to have important indirect effects in the groundcover because the foliage it produces are important fuels in this fire-dependent ecosystem.

Beyond our main experiment, this award also supported the research of two M.S. biology students and one Ph.D. student. The project by the first M.S. student was the converse or our main experiment; she studied the influence of neighboring groundcover plants on wiregrass in sandhills and seepage slopes by measuring the effect on wiregrass following removal of neighboring plants. She found that neighbors promoted growth of wiregrass in the sandhills, reduced growth of wiregrass in seepage slopes, and increased wiregrass reproductive output in both habitats. We also predicted that nearby longleaf pines would suppress grass growth because of shading and water competition, but surprisingly, she found that pines beyond the immediate neighborhood increased wiregrass growth and reproduction in both habitats.

The second M.S. student examined “home soil effects” and plant-plant interactions among wiregrass and a second dominant bunchgrass species, little bluestem. He planted combinations of four tussocks from the two species into pots of either their native soil or the soil of their in-pot neighbors. He collected the soil and all tussocks at Eglin AFB. He found that tussocks of both species grew best in pots containing mostly the opposite species, and he found no noticeable effect of soil type. Wiregrass individuals planted with all bluestem tussocks grew more belowground, whereas bluestem individuals planted with all wiregrass tussocks grew more aboveground.

The Ph.D. student tested for non-random spatial patterns in dominant bunchgrasses at Eglin AFB and across the southeastern United States using sophisticated spatial statistics to assess dispersion patterns of the grass tussocks. She found that the dominant bunchgrasses were significantly more regularly spaced than expected by chance. This suggests competition among the bunchgrasses keeps them apart, and this spacing allows opportunities for smaller plants to survive among the large bunchgrasses that might otherwise shade them out. This could be an important mechanism underpinning high species diversity in many grasslands.

We convened a workshop with the 2014 joint Longleaf Alliance and Eastern Native Grass Conference in Mobile, Alabama. The workshop brought together 37 ecologists and natural resource professionals to discuss the science of managing and restoring the longleaf ecosystem. The event was an unqualified success, and participants left motivated both to convene more focused workshops at future Longleaf Alliance Conferences and to influence policy by recognizing land owners’ efforts to re-establish groundcover biodiversity on private lands. We submitted our synthesis to the America’s Longleaf Partnership Council to motivate policy changes that better include groundcover biodiversity in restoration incentive programs.
